full articles.article:
matters in debate, resolves all doubts and
eases the mind and conscience of all their
scruples. 1t reveals the only living and true
Con, and shows the way to him; and sets
aside all other gods, and describes the vanl-
ty of them, and of all that put their trust III
them. In short, it is a hook OF laws, to show
right and wrong; a book OF wisdom that con-
demns all folly and make the foolish wise;
book of truth that detects all lies, and con-
flutes all errers, and a book of life that shows
the way from everlasting death. 1t is the
most compendious book i'll the world; the
most authentic and entertaining history that
ever was published; it contains the most
early antiquities, strange events, wonderful
occurrences, heroic deeds, and unparalleled
wars. 1t describes the celestial, terrestrial
and Internal worlds, and the origin OF the an
gcical myriatls, human tribes, and internal


egions. 1t will instruct the most skiltul me-
chanic, and the finest artist, 1t Will teach the
best rhetorician, and exercise every power
of the NEST expert arithmetician; puzzle the
wIsest anatomst, and exercise the incest
critic. 1t corrects the VAIN philosopher aiit
guides the wise astronomer, 1t exposes the
subtle sophist, and makesthe dlviner mad. ~
is complete code Of laws, a perfect noay o,
divinity, an unequalled narrative; DOCK nl
lives. a book of travels, a book of voyages
It is the best covenant that ever was agrcef
On the best deed that ever was sealed, th.
hest evidence that ever was produced, an'
the best testament that ever was signed. -
I To understand it, is to be wise indeed. to b(
ignorant Of it, is to be destitute OF wisdom.--
1t is the kings best copy, the magistrate
hest rule, the housewives best guide, tht
servants best directory, and the young man


best companion. 1t IS the school boys spell


ing book. and the learned mans maste'


piece. 1t contains choice grammar Tor


novice, and profound treatise tor sAsq


it is the ignorant mans dictionary az


fords knowledge Of witty inventions tor TN


ingenious; and dry sayings for the grave; an'


il is its own interpreter. 1t encourages IN


wise, the warrior, the racer and the over


conner; and promises an eternal reward


the conoueror. And that which crowns al


is that the Author is l"without hypocrisy


in whom is no variablencss, nor shadow


turning"

NY WAsIII SGTOX IRVING.
full articles.article:
epdeavorcd to learn the story of the i'll
fated Ellen and the interesting mourner
whom had beheld lowering over her ash
es; and found that they were indeed the
panes of a mothers heart. which had caus'
ed the Grief had witnessed. She had at
tended her husband abroad, through many
a scene of trial and hardship, she had dress
ed his wounds upon the day of Battle, and
|. she had watched over her soldiers lowly
pallet, with firm and unremitting tender
ness; bnt his wounds were healed, and he
rose from his sick bed, astonlshed at her
macnanimitv, and grateful for her affection.
They returned together to their native coun-
try. that they might seek reward tor their
mast suffrrings in the bosom OF the country
that paye them birth, and in the happy re
tirement which they best loved. Several
children blesscd their union; but some were
npped in the bud of infancy, and the rest
prematnrely destroyed, ere yet they were
tully unfot,cd into blossoms. One beloved
dauphter--their beautiful Ellen--alonc re-
NAMED 70 them. All the tender shoots
were wtherrd save this one; and her
they cherished as their sole remaining PRIDE,
their only surviving prop. lhat chiid grew
up ali that her doating parents wished, aaa
I lovely in mind as in person, shc construed
their sum OF happiness on earth. but alas


the sweetest and most delicate tlawers are
often nipped the soonest ny the Call wina
or by the blighting underwater trasii'
form but too easily sunk under the pressure
Of disease, ami like a tender reed bent DC
meath its own unsupported weight. ile'
ewes. indeed, spark!el with unusual lustre


INIT II was no more like the briliance Q
health than the false glare OF a WANDERING
meteor resembles the clear and steady el


fulprnce of the meridian sun; and though


bright bloom colored her cheek, 1t Was no


the rosy tint of vigor, but the harbngcr o


annroaching ruin. The terrified pan ents be
. held with horror, the dreadful symptoms
, In an agony of mind, which none besides cal
fn,lv anDreciate they tried all that natur


dictated, or art devised, to stop the prosres
Of the fatal malady. But it was too late
1t made rapid and gigantic strides; and mop
itself was soon obliged to droop in anguish
i The lovely victim saw her fate before hei
! INT her wines were plumed for Heaven, an


She wished not to hover longer upon tn
:, earth While her body dropped and Ian
, puished. her mind became strengthened AN
! fortified; and the undecaying spirit SCENE


to ching forth more vislby, and more oeau


tifnIIv. when the mortal shroud winch en-
+. veloned il was gradually failing. At lenst
: l;fr gradually wancd- and waned, until II
6 lamn shot up one light, but qulverlng gleaI
. and was then darkened for ever one wa
flead-but the rose still lived on her chcci
4 and smile still played upon the hait clo'
i ed lips, whose last accents had oreathea u,
{ fond name of mother And those VINO ioof
: ed upon her could scarcely believe out tha
n she sweetly slept.

full articles.headline: WHAT Is LOVE LIKE
full articles.article:
What is io4c like
Like buttcsh,'s wing
Wien rich with the perfumes of early spring -
Ike the varied hnes Of the ranbows' form
Investing with pomp passing storn;-
like the signing nght-winds stcalthy creep
10 lull the wild flower TO its Sleep
Like the glow worms light, or the meteor


CLEAN,
Or the smile that waits on an infants dream
What is love like


Like the brightest ray,
That worships the sun in his proud display
Like the charm that nestlcs in bcauty's eye,
Or the strains of witchng melody
Like those sweet thoughts which steal ut ever
70 win the soul from earth to heaven,
That bids it live beyond the sky,
Where all is peace and purity. EuoENE.

ol when the growing winds contend, and all

From the New Monthly Ma gazine.
THE HUNTING ALDERMAN.
full articles.article:
Snow let us sing long live the king.


And Gilpin long live he;


And when he next doth ride abroad,


May be there to ee."-John Gilpnn.


"Who has e'er been in Paris must needs
know the Greve,' says Prior's song, and it
is almost equally impossible for any one to
have been in the neighborhood of Taunton.
at least if he hare any venatorial blood IN
his veins, without knowing the worthy
Squire Tasborough, the staunchcst Nimrod
left to us since Colonel Thornton, OF sport
ing celebrity, was unfortunate enough TO DC
at his own death. "Fifty gulneas to hve,
cried the Squire to party OF hunting COM
panions, who were giving no respite to the
marnnms of claret at his own table.--"ffty
cuineas to ten that the alderman won't turn
out with us next Friday" "--"Done" cried
old Major Cunningham.- "And five hundred
guineas to fifty," roared the Squire. that ne


won't be in at the death" "Dcne to that too,'
replied the MAJOR; 81 always take the long
odds.n 1t was bet, and regularly entered
in their pocket books by the respective par


ties.


am not at liberty TO give any other clue


TO the Alderman in question, than by stat
! ing that he purchased an estate about TWO


wears ago in Somersetshire, which will prob


ably be sufficient guide to my civic read


ers, and that he was hardly ever known 20


have been on horseback in his life; the lnVi-


tation to the hunt had been sent TO hun as a


mere frolic, although it had produced the


very serious bets have recorded. Other


wagers arose out of these, ut mos esq psn@-


toribus. and as considerable interest had


been excited by their ridiculous nature,


resolved to be in the field, and witness their


termination. The day appointed for the


hunt was one ofthosc misty, dewy, drizzllng


mornings of October, which seems to be an


authorization Of the succeeding month and to


leave YOU in doubt whether it will settle In


to a confirmed rain, or sparkle up into


fresh, buoyant, invigorating day. Euston


Common the place Of rendezvous, runs into


a thicket OF oaks and underwood, sloping


down with an easy descent to Ihorley bot


tom. Through this copse line winds and


emerecs into the lower common, where


SQUIRE Tashborough with his huntsmen,


hounds, and merry men all, the greater part
, of them in scarlet coats. and velvet caps.


were assembled, the former already tri.


umphing over the Major, in the anticipated
certainty Of winning his wager. what =
j he exclaimed, "do you think old square-toes
would turn out with mist falling, and run
the risk of dampng his drab CATERS! No.
no Maior--you'r done this time-eascd OF
vour ten puineas--I wish it had been thou-
! sand"
"TasLstough," said the Major, quietly
Duttinc his rlass to his eye, "your sight is
i better than mine, what do you make that
bird to be, lowering along the copsef-
) "lIang me if can tell, replied the Squire;
"ilics like wounded crow--can't see for the
o mist The object in question was no otn-
, cr than the Alderman's hat. tied down with
: la pocket handkerchief, and popping occa-


sionally above the hedge as he logged down
q the lane. at the extremity OF which he pre-
. sented himself mounted on grey Poneys
{ and followed by his servant on coach- morse,
. bearing large umbrella. general snout
L in which the Squires voice was iouaest,
II burst from the whole field at the slgnt OF TINS
: rrotesoue apparation. whose approach was
> rreeted by loud cry Of Yoicks, Tally-ho
= and signal was made to the huntsman to
= wind his horn, by way ot completing the
n eclas of his reception. But old Chervil, who
) had no idea of Joke that intcrtered with Sc
% rions buniness, shook his head cxclalming
If NO not when we are just going to throw
- into cover; she may start away tother side
= for the four ponds, and SO get among the


rush beds. aud keep usSdodging in the watel
! all day. have known them to do It nun
1t drcd times"


Nv this time the Alderman had come nI
!. moDpinrhis chest, arms and long ciotn Sai
- tors with his handkerchief, and having
, snread out his umbrella he exclaimed
II .M,ke 1t a rule to see every thing at once
n in nv life, Mr.. Tasborough;-never went
IN hunting afore;-s'pose shan't so now foi
ID of course YOU won't SO IN the rai'i--no mack
e. ney coach to pop into-don't object to th'
is country when the sun shines-but nothiht
.e like London in wet weather." My goot
re sir" replied the Squire, nothing could os
: more faynrablc-a beautiful drizzle, ane
y lust enough to make the scent life-but you
ir warm" ..Ay, ay," cried Major Cunning
- ham. ..hc'll be warmer by the time he's II
: If the DEATH mo, no, Major" resumes
ID the Squire, speaking so as not to be over
il. heard "I'm safe enough there, for that pot
i. brllicd pony will be blown in ten minutes
,e 50 | shall only lose fifty. and that's NOR
,e than the old codger's worth, to take him a
d. he sits, umbrella, clothes. pony, CATERS an
ne ALL"
y The object of these remarks now torme
ii Nthe centre of a gaping circle, the real know
as ing ones "twiggins him properly with
te Quiet sneer, or u sly wink to direct one al
4 others ewes to the various hcrlsles of his az
3. nointment; while a few farmers assembled tc
th rether in knot at a little distance, with the
no ragged ponies touching noses, and doing an
ms podding at one another, unanimously agree
.ir that "for gemman and sportsman, 1t wei

flowers, and was curious to observe the ef'
feet of winter upon this singular receptacle
of Death, when the earth was covered with
snow and unbroken solitude reigncd AMID
those walks which are so thronged with vls-
itors in the pleasant season OF revivlng nature.
I leaving the Boulevards at the opening OF the
Souare in which the Bastile once stood, ~
turned down the street named la Roquette,
the extremity of which is entirely occupied
by the workshop of one-Cutters, and
of railings and all the other
paraphernalia of the grave, and entered at
the great CRATE, preceded by melancholy
procession. about to add one more lite,ess
relic of mortality to the thousands already
deposited in this teeming Empire of Death.
Turning out of the broad walk which pas
ses through the middle of the cementery,
proceeded along sequestered path that
leads to the corner nearest the open neius
beyond the CITY. In this secluded spot the
cnrions visitor is attracted to a little Gothic
Chapel. inst seen above the thick groves OF
cvprus in which it is embosomed whose ex-
auisite proportions, and light and graceful ar
chtecture seem to announce the resting Piace
of some mortal whose lot on earth has not
been only to live his little span--to die--ahd
be forgotten It's form Is square, open at
the side s. and covered by an angular dome
of singular beauty, supported py u slender
Dil,ars and surmounted by delicate and


graceful spre of open carved stone with
Smaller ornaments Of "A similar form at the
corners ;-heneath this canopy, upon ties.
selated pavement of white and black marble,
rest an alter tomb bearing the cfgles OF
them whose ashes sleep below. Their yes
ture is that of the convent, and their hands
are elasped in the attitude OF supplication-
II is the sepulchre of Abelard and Helolse


This is the ASYLUM wh.re, at length, the re-
mains of those unfortunate lovers repose TO-
pethcr the memory of whose guilt is eilaced
IN our admiration Of their genius, and our
commisseraton for their unhappy destiny.


AsI stood beside their grave, and REGAL
led the melancholy story OF their loves and
their misfortunes, the gloomy scene around
me faded from my view, and my ina ',inat'oh
o'erpassing the long ages that nave foiled a.
wav since they were consigned to inc
dust, brought them before me IS they moved
on earth, in all the splendour OF their youth


FIJI heauty. while their young hearts were
Glowing with the warm tide Of passion.
while the current of their etlstance ilowcd
smoothly along through blooming groves
and sunny mcads, rich with the balmy breath
of sprng and the warblng of heavenly mu-
sic. and while drinking deep OF the ihtoxl-
eating Gun of love and pleasure, they forgot
ftbe world and all its cares, thinking only OF
. each other, seeing only Smiles and beauty,
tnowiny only that they loved and were loved
again saw the fearful storm that came
to shed despair and sorrow and desoiatloi
over tbis fair picture OF felicity the victims
of !. crncl yencence. / beheld them TORI
from each other; imprisoned, suffering, for
hidden by their wretched destiny even Il
